headline: CNN Special Reports
subHeadline: American Coup: The January 6th Investigation. Aired 10-11p ET

utterances.speaker: JAKE TAPPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: What's the bottom line you want the American people to know?REP. LIZ CHENEY (R-WY): There was a very sophisticated multipart plan overseen by Donald Trump. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) DONALD J. TRUMP, 45TH US PRESIDENT: You can't ever accept when they steal and rake and rob. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: To attempt to stay in power.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: As the longest largest investigation into Donald Trump's attempt to stay president comes to a close, we put it all together.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I've got three men walking down the street, one carrying AR-15.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The explosive testimony.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CASSIDY HUTCHINSON, FORMER WHITE HOUSE AIDE
utterances.sentences: I ever heard the President say something to the effect of I don't think [BEEP] that they have weapons, let my people in.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: New insight from witnesses.

utterances.speaker: RUSSELL BOWERS, FORMER ARIZONA STATE REPRESENTATIVE
utterances.sentences: I said you want me to take my state 3.2 million voters and just throw them out the window?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Was he asking you to commit a crime?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It gets back to the criminal intent issue. I don't know what he believed.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And what might lie ahead.

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL LUTTIG, RETIRED FORMER FEDERAL COURT JUDGE
utterances.sentences: The former president and his allies represent a clear and present danger to American democracy, not because of what they did on January 6, it's because of what they pledged to do in 2024.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: A CNN Special Report, American Coup

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: I'm a very textural artist. I love a lot of texture.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: In Arizona, the Republican Speaker of the House, Rusty Bowers is an artist by trade. But last February Bowers was thrown into a real-life drama.

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: The bill number was 2596.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: 2596, one of more than 100 bills submitted in Arizona to tighten access to the ballot box. The measure would have scrapped early voting, all voting would be on election day, only.

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: 90 percent of my district votes early.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And it would have mandated paper ballots but most egregious to Rusty Bowers was this.

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: With no guidance criteria, the legislature after the election could dismiss the election. And I said welcome to fascism.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: HB 2596 elections.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: And so, I said, I will give this the respect it deserves.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Education.

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: So, I sent it to 12 committees. So, we would have a long vetting process.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Military affairs.

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: Typical is one or two. If it was a controversial bill, you might send it to three. If it goes to four committees then then you're getting the message.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Judiciary.

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: I assigned it to 12 committees.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Transportation.

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: It was theatrical, and I admit it.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: It's no overstatement to say that because Bowers stood up for democracy he will no longer be in the state legislature.

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: I'm Rusty Bowers.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Term limited in the state house, he ran in the Republican primary for a state Senate seat.

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: That stood up to the radicals and kept my conservative campaign promises. My opponents David Farnsworth.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: David Farnsworth is going to do the job.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Their positions on the major issues nearly identical, except for one.SEN. DAVID FARNSWORTH (R-AZ): I believe the election was stolen.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Farnsworth bought into Trump's election lies. Bowers did not.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Arizona voters have picked David Farnsworth over state House Speaker.

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: My last bill. It is very possible that the bill that I've assigned liberally to my committees will be back. Possibility of that getting a governor signature would just be a disaster. I call it the possibility of going back into the dark ages in Arizona.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: As the U.S. heading into the 2022 midterm elections, there was perhaps more at stake regarding American democracy than ever before. From Arizona to Pennsylvania to Georgia, in all the so-called swing States, the former President Donald Trump, backed not only those who supported his lies about election fraud in 2020, but also often those who expressed a willingness to undo any future results that they don't like under the pretense of Trumped-up fraud.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: As this was happening, the House Select Committee investigating January 6 was interviewing witnesses, holding hearings and gathering evidence to fully expose what the committee says was a plot designed to keep Donald Trump as president in 2020 and to try to make sure it can never happen again.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: What's the bottom line you want the American people to know from these hearings?

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: There are several things, but one is that there was a very sophisticated multipart plan overseen by Donald Trump to attempt to overturn the election. No president in our history has ever done anything even close to that before.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Vice Chair Liz Cheney, one of just two Republicans on the committee, has spent the last year bucking her party and helping investigate Donald Trump's sophisticated multipart plan. The first piece the committee focused on were the lies.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Mail ballots' a very dangerous thing for this country because they're cheaters.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: In the lead up to the election Donald Trump had been talking about the possibility of widespread voter fraud for months.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: voting by mail is wrought with fraud. People steal them out of mailboxes.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Looking back, it's clear he was laying the groundwork for this.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: This is a fraud on the American public. This is an embarrassment to our country. We were getting ready to win this election. Frankly, we did win this election.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Trump may have been crying widespread fraud, but he had no proof. What the former President did have proof of based on his own team's assessment of votes was that he lost. A fact made clear by the January 6 committee which exposed to the world that so many Trump aides despite toeing the Trump line in public.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Are you expecting the president to concede.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Maria that words not even in our vocabulary right now.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Knew Trump was going to lose legitimately and that he did lose legitimately, admissions they were forced to make under oath.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) JASON MILLER, FORMER TRUMP CAMPAIGN ADVISER: I was in the Oval Office. And at some point in the conversation, Matt Oczkowski, who is the lead data person was brought on and I remember he delivered to the president pretty blunt terms that he was going to lose. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Trump campaign attorneys followed up on all of the fraud claims and they quickly concluded that fraud did not take the election from Donald Trump, voters did. The news was told to Trump's Chief of Staff at the White House Mark Meadows in mid to late November.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ALEX CANNON, FORMER TRUMP CAMPAIGN LAWYER
utterances.sentences: I remember a call with Mr. Meadows and I remember sharing with him that we weren't finding anything that would be sufficient to change the results in any of the key States.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: During a meeting several weeks later, the President got the same message from his White House Counsel Pat Cipollone, and another White House lawyer Eric Herschmann.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DEREK LYONS, FORMER WHITE HOUSE STAFF SECRETARY FOR TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Eric and Pat told the group President included that none of those allegations had been substantiated to the point where they can be the basis for any litigation challenge to the election.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: It is statistically impossible that the person me that led the charge lost.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But Donald Trump continued to refuse to publicly accept defeat.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: The evidence of the fraud is monumental and more is coming out.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Audacious claims of widespread fraud became a daily occurrence.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Numerous times we found glitches, and every single time that glitch went 100 percent to Biden, and no percent to Trump.

utterances.speaker: RUDY GIULIANI, FORMER TRUMP ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: The only thing left is the vote. That could have been Mickey Mouse. That could have been a dead person. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Standing near Giuliani is an attorney named Sidney Powell, who became the face of one of the most notorious and frankly, most deranged lies that Dominion voting machines were flipping votes for Trump to Biden.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SIDNEY POWELL, FORMER FEDERAL PROSECUTOR
utterances.sentences: The Dominion voting systems were created in Venezuela, at the direction of Hugo Chavez to make sure he never lost an election.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: After she was sued by Dominion, Powell's attorney eventually conceded that Powell lied, saying that "no reasonable person would conclude that her statements were truly statements of fact."But long before that happened. The president's Attorney General Bill Barr was investigating all of Trump's fraud claims. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) BILL BARR, FORMER U.S. ATTORNEY GENERAL: It was a little -- getting a little awkward because obviously he had lost the election and -- (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Barr said he made it clear to Donald Trump in the November 23 meeting that he had lost.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BARR
utterances.sentences: Our role is to investigate fraud and it's just not meritorious. They're not panning -- panning out.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: He was going to win in spite of all the fraud.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But spurred on by the most ardent election liars, including many in MAGA media.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Clearly the president won this election.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump would not listen to reason or fact.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Missing in action.

utterances.speaker: BARR
utterances.sentences: This got under my skin but I also felt it was time for me to say something so I set up a lunch with the AP reporter Mike Balsamo and I told him that to date we have not seen fraud on a scale that could have affected a different outcome in the election.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: A heated Trump-Barr meeting followed and Barr got another opportunity to debunk the lies. Among the claims he focused on were the ones about Dominion voting machines.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: With a turn of a dial with a change of a chip, you can press a button for Trump and the vote goes to Biden.

utterances.speaker: BARR
utterances.sentences: I told him that the stuff that his people were shoveling out to the public was bullshit. I specifically raised the Dominion voting machines. I saw absolutely zero basis for the allegations, but they were made in such a sensational way that they obviously were influencing a lot of people.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Before the end of December, Barr had quit. His replacement, Acting Attorney General Jeffrey Rosen, who came with a blunt yet low key Acting Deputy Attorney General named Richard Donoghue. Like Barr, Rosen and Donoghue took seriously and thoroughly investigated each of the fraud claims coming from then President Trump.In late December Donoghue spoke with the President and told him the truth about numerous false claims, including one involving Dominion machines in northern Michigan. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RICHARD DONOGHUE, ACTING UNITED STATES DEPUTY ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.sentences: There you had supposedly a cyber expert group issue a report that said there was a 68 percent error rate. It was not a 68 percent error rate. In fact, it was, I think, a point 0.006 percent error rate.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Donoghue also debunked fraud claims Trump made about the vote counting done at the State Farm Arena in Atlanta, Georgia.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't run to see if people are walking in with suitcases and putting them under a table with a black robe around it.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: There were allegations about suitcases of fraudulent ballots being smuggled into the facility.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Now they're going to start pulling these ballots out from under this table.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: Ballots being run through multiple times. The U.S. attorney there looked at it found that none of those allegations were true.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Donoghue's boss Jeff Rosen, then forwarded an email from the White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows, asking the Department of Justice to look into the possibility that Italian satellites were changing votes from Trump to Biden.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) BRADLEY JOHNSON, CIA CHIEF OF STATION (RET): They sent these new numbers back up through this Military satellite, Italian Military satellite.

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: I was skeptical to say the least. We very quickly determined that that was not a well-founded allegation. And we told the Chief of Staff and others as well.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: Whiskey Tango Foxtrot. I mean, what's going on over there? What were these games?(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The nation's top law enforcement officials were investigating and finding nothing substantive. And in the courts the usual venue for claims about voting misconduct, the President's team lost over and over again.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Courts again shutting down more desperate attempts to overturn an election.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You're on George W. Bush's shortlist for the Supreme Court. You're not some raging liberal. Is that fair?

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: Totally fair.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Michael Luttig is a highly respected conservative retired Federal Court Judge. Luttig did not hear any of the Trump fraud cases. But he and his colleagues did analyze more than 60 of them.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: We reviewed each individual claim and decided that there was nothing that would have changed the result in a single precinct, let alone a single state, let alone nationally.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Ahead.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: You're asking me to do something that's against my oath. And I'm not going to do that.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump puts the squeeze on Statehouse leaders across the country.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: We're in my office, this is the Speaker's office.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: It's not every day a State House politician gets a call from a U.S. President. But that's what happened to Arizona Speaker Republican Rusty Bowers after the 2020 election.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: Came home from church. My wife and I were sitting in the driveway.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The White House popped up on his screen.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: So, I take the call and Danette steps out, goes in the house. I sat there in my little Prius and had a chat with the President with bad phone reception and backed out in front of the house where I get better reception.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Rudy Giuliani was on the line to and Bowers says it was Giuliani who began making crazy claims about voter fraud in Arizona. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: I can't give you the exact numbers, but -- I'll throw out numbers but they're kind of, of the audacious numbers, like 200,000 illegal aliens voted, 6000 Military ballots were stolen and used.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Bowers says Giuliani wanted him to hold an official Arizona House hearing to air these claims publicly.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: And then I said, but what's the whole purpose of this? What are you trying to achieve? And they said, well, we've heard that there's an arcane law in Arizona that if you have sufficient cause that you can throw out the Biden electors and put in Trump electors.And I said, that's a new one to me. I have never, ever heard of that. And so now you're asking me to do something that's against my oath. And I'm not going to do that. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But Bowers says he told Giuliani he had good lawyers and would be happy to put the former mayor in touch with them.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: I don't do anything of this magnitude without having strong legal counsel and proof. And the President says Rudy, you got the proof. He said, Yes, I got the proof. I said, I want the proof. I didn't get it when he said he'd do it. He never called my attorneys.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But the asks did not stop with Giuliani. Bowers would later get a call from another Trump attorney, John Eastman.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We know there was fraud.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Whom the January 6 Committee sees as a key player in this grand plan to undo the legitimate results of the 2020 presidential election.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: The Ask was kind of that we would throw out the electors. And I said has it ever been done? He said, no. I said you want me to take my state, 3.2 million voters and just throw them out the window because I want to and that's responsible on my part. I said, OK, thank you. We're not doing that. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: When they got the cyber ninjas, I thought, I'll watch this will be interesting. I don't want to be close to that.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You might remember the ninjas the company was run by a Trump supporter. They employed ultraviolet lights which could supposedly identify ballots from China.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BOWERS
utterances.sentences: Then came out that Mr. Biden won by a larger margin than previously and Mr. Trump lost a number of votes.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Bowers in his colleagues in Arizona were not the only state officials to feel the heat from Trump and or Giuliani. Material discovered by the January 6 committee showed it happened over and over across the swing States that Biden one.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: Mr. Speaker, this is Rudy Giuliani and Jenna Ellis.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: In Pennsylvania Bowers counterpart, Republican House Speaker Bryan Cutler, got the calls.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JENNA ELLIS
utterances.sentences: Hello, Mr. Speaker. This is Jenna Ellis and I'm here with Mayor Giuliani.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: Hey, Bryan, it's Rudy. I really have something important to call your attention, that I think really changes things.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The January 6 committee says Cutler thought the calls were inappropriate and had his lawyers tell Giuliani to stop them.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: I understand that you don't want to talk to me now. I just want to bring some facts to your attention.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And then there was Georgia where the Republican Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger got an hour-long call from President Trump.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Brad, what are we going to do? We won the election and it's not fair to take it away from us like this.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Trump probably put more pressure on Brad Raffensperger than anyone else. It was immense.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: All I want to do is this. I just want to find 11,780 votes.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And I think it's the phone call that everyone remembers that was later leaked, where he in turn berated Brad Raffensperger.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: They're going around playing you and laughing at you behind your back, Brad.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: He praised him. He seemed to try to charm him at times and even indicated that if he did not act, that there could be criminal liability for those actions.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You're not reporting it. That says hey, you know that's a criminal, that's a criminal offense.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And it was not just pressure. There were threats, usually from Trump supporters who felt empowered or incited by him. Take for instance the two men in this Hummer with a QAnon decal. Prosecutors say they drove the vehicle filled with automatic weapons and ammunition from Virginia to the Philadelphia Convention Center in early November 2020, where votes were still being counted.At the time, Al Schmidt was the Republican responsible for overseeing the vote count in Philadelphia. He received threats aimed at his family. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) AL SCHMIDT, FORMER REPUBLICAN COMMISSIONER OF PHILADELPHIA: Tell the truth or your three kids will be fatally shot. Included our address, included my children's names, included a picture of our home. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And the Republican House Speaker in that state had protesters show up at his home.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) BRYAN CUTLER, (R) PENNSYLVANIA HOUSE SPEAKER: There were multiple protests at least three outside of either my district office or my home. My then 15-year-old son was home by himself for the first one. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: In Georgia, Brad Raffensperger's wife received disturbing messages.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BRAD RAFFENSPERGER, GEORGIA SECRETARY OF STATE
utterances.sentences: People started threatening her, sending her sexualized texts, those kinds of intimidations.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Georgia election worker Shaye Moss testified before the House Select Committee about threats she received via Facebook Messenger.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SHAYE MOSS, GEORGIA ELECTION WORKER
utterances.sentences: A lot of threats wishing death upon me, telling me that I'll be in jail with my mother.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: These threats happened after Rudy Giuliani spread lies about her and her mother Ruby Freeman, who was counting votes with moss at State Farm Arena in Atlanta on election night.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: Tape earlier in the day of Ruby Freeman and Shaye Freeman Moss and one other gentleman quite obviously surreptitiously passing around USB ports as if they're vials of heroin or cocaine. I mean, it's -- it's obvious to anyone who's a criminal investigator or prosecutor, they are engaged in surreptitious illegal activity.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What was your mom actually handing you on that video?

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: A Ginger Mint. This turned my life upside down. I don't want anyone knowing my name. I don't want to go anywhere with my mom because she might yell my name out over the grocery aisle or something. I haven't been anywhere at all. I gained about 60 pounds. This affect my life in a major way.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Up next.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: After six weeks of lies and pressure from the president of the United States-(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Take a moment to mark your ballots.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: -- on December 14, 2020, all 50 U.S. States formerly certified their results as their citizens had voted.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The resolution is unanimously adopted.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And that, according to the January 6 committee, is what led to a boisterous White House meeting where the former President considered horrifying action. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MAGGIE HABERMAN, SENIOR POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT, NEW YORK TIMES
utterances.sentences: On December 18, three people, one of them Trump's former National Security Adviser Mike Flynn, his lawyer, Sidney Powell, and Patrick Byrne, the founder of overstock.com, were let into the White House by an aide to Peter Navarro, another Trump adviser.Trump saw them, called them into the Oval Office, and they start arguing the case where everyone else is failing Trump and that Trump can take aggressive actions to keep himself in power, and to try to impact the results of an election that he had already lost. They suggested that he used the apparatus of government to cease voting machines. And as this meeting is taking place, another lawyer in the White House, Eric Herschmann figures out what's happening, calls in the White House Counsel Pat Cipollone, Mark Meadows ends up joining at some point, Derek Lyons then the Staff Secretary on his last day at work joins. Rudy Giuliani gets pulled in. And this goes on four hours. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: How much time did you have alone with the President and I say alone, you had other people with you but before the crowd came running.

utterances.speaker: POWELL
utterances.sentences: Oh, probably no more than 10 or 15 minutes. I bet Pat Cipollone set a new land speed record.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I opened the door, and I walked in, I saw General Flynn, I saw Sidney Powell sitting there. I was not happy to see the people in the Oval Office. I don't think any of these people were providing the President with good advice.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The team had arrived with a draft executive order that had it been signed by Donald Trump would have immediately ordered the Secretary of Defense to cease collect, retain and analyze ballot boxes. And it would have created, quote, a special counsel to oversee the operation and institute all criminal and civil proceedings as appropriate.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: This is a draft of the executive order that would have allowed Trump to seize voting machines. What was your reaction when you heard about this?

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: I think most Americans could never imagine those things would happen here. And that order, and many of the other things that we've learned through our hearings have been really stunning to me, because repeatedly, I found myself in a situation thinking, my gosh, how could this happen here? And we really thought it couldn't. But it's just continued to emphasize for all of us that that our institutions are fragile.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The appointment of the Special Counsel was not hypothetical. Trump wanted Sidney Powell; a prominent peddler of election lies in this spot.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: POWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's the baloney if he had the authority to name a special counsel, and he said yes. And then he asked him if he had the authority to give me whatever security clearance I need and Cipollone said yes.And then the President said, OK, you know, I'm naming her that and I'm giving her security clearance. And then shortly before we left was when Cipollone and or Herschmann and whoever the other young man was said, you can name her whatever you want to name her and no one's going to pay any attention to it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: How did he respond? How did the President respond to that?

utterances.speaker: POWELL
utterances.sentences: Something like you see what I deal with. I deal with this all the time.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The meeting was extremely heated, with Cipollone arguing against the Special Counsel idea and against seizure of voting machines.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PAT CIPOLLONE, FORMER WHITE HOUSE COUNSEL
utterances.sentences: To have the federal government seize voting machines, that's a terrible idea for the country. That's not how we do things in the United States. There's no legal authority to do that. The three of them were really sort of forcefully attacking me, verbally.Eric, Derek, and we are pushing back and we're asking one simple question. As a general matter, where's the evidence?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What response did you get?

utterances.speaker: CIPOLLONE
utterances.sentences: A variety of responses. Like what do you mean, where's the Evidence. You should know.

utterances.speaker: LYONS
utterances.sentences: There was a discussion of well, you know, we don't have it now but we will have it or whatever.

utterances.speaker: HERSCHMANN
utterances.sentences: Derek and I both challenged what she was saying. And she says, well, the judges are corrupt. And I was like every one? Every single case that you've done in the country, you guys lost, every one of them is corrupt? Even the ones we appointed? And --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What's-

utterances.speaker: HERSCHMANN
utterances.sentences: I'm being nice. I was much more harsh to her.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HERSCHMANN
utterances.sentences: Flynn screamed at me that I was a quitter and everything, kept on standing up and turning around and screaming at me. And then a certain point I had it with him, though, and I yelled back, either come over or set your [BEEP] ass back down.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: I'm going to categorically describe it as you guys are not tough enough. Or maybe I put it another way, you're a bunch of [BEEP]. Excuse the expression, but that's -- I'm almost certain the word was used.

utterances.speaker: POWELL
utterances.sentences: I mean, if it had been me sitting in his chair, I would have fired all of them that night and had him escorted out of the building. The January 6 committee discovered text messages sent during and following the meeting by Cassidy Hutchinson, the Assistant to Mark Meadows, who testified live before the committee hearing in June, describing the meeting as unhinged.She also snapped this photograph of Mark Meadows escorting Rudy Giuliani from the White House, to make sure he did not get back into the mansion. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You tweeted, quote, somehow the committee testimony featured live underplayed how crazy that December 18th meeting was, how was it underplayed?

utterances.speaker: HABERMAN
utterances.sentences: Because Donald Trump faded into the background, as this was all being described in one of the ways in which Donald Trump has escaped a lot of accountability over time, is he gets people fighting with each other. And that's what people focus on. He considered extreme, really unprecedented actions.Now, he didn't take them, but he was unwilling to foreclose options until the last possible second, no matter how extreme and -- and potentially dangerous they were.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: I remember talking to you after that meeting, and you were shaking.

utterances.speaker: HABERMAN
utterances.sentences: I was. And it was, frankly, it took a little bit of process exactly what had happened. But I remember getting a text from a senior Republican Senate advisor, asking me if there was going to be an issue in terms of a peaceful transfer of power after this. And I said, yes, there is a legitimate issue here.And I think that was a real neon warning sign.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: It was floated this idea by retired General Michael Flynn, in the Oval Office, that Donald Trump should cease voting machines and ballot boxes from these States that Joe Biden won. What was your reaction when you heard that?

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: I said, to my wife, this is beyond all comprehension. I never utter a word like this. But -- but that in particular sounded in a Banana Republic to me. Had that happened, we would have been in a situation where literally, we're in a constitutional crisis, because nothing in our Constitution gives you the answer.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: At the end of the evening, no seizure orders were issued, the President decided to go in a different direction. He would take it in a tweet.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: What he wanted was to show everyone who was telling him he lost the election and that people agreed with him.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Hours before sunrise on December 19, 2020, after a long, loud, disturbing White House meeting about seizing voting machines, President Trump sent a tweet that would change history.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PROTESTORS
utterances.sentences: USA USA.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: "Big protests in DC on January 6," it read. Be there, will be wild."

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: What he wanted was to show these lawmakers not just in Washington, but everyone who was telling him he lost the election. He wanted to show them that people agreed with him and people back to his lies about the election.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump was summoning his true believers to Washington DC and evidence pieced together by the January 6 committee shows they heard that call and began planning immediately.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) REP. JAMIE RASKIN (D-MD): Women for America First, a pro-Trump organizing group had previously applied for rally permit for January 22 and 23rd in Washington DC. But in the hours after the tweet, they moved their permit to January 6. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The next day Ali Alexander, a Trump supporter and leader of the group 'Stop the Steal' created a website to share and promote logistics about the rally.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RASKIN
utterances.sentences: It included event times, places speakers and details on transportation to Washington DC.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Far Right personalities such as Conspiracy theorist Alex Jones almost immediately began spreading the word on their platforms.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ALEX JONES, RIGHT WONG MEDIA PERSONALITY
utterances.sentences: One of the most historic events in American history has just taken place. President Trump wants the American people to march on Washington DC on January 6, 2021. The time for games is over. The time for action is now.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: As word spread, it became clear that Trump faithful who plan to attend were also planning for the possibility of violence.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The term Red Wedding comes from the Game of Thrones TV series. It means a massacre.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CRACKER
utterances.sentences: January 6, kick that [BEEP] door open, look down the street, there are going to be a million plus geeked up on the barricades.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Some of Trump's Twitter followers did consider his tweets to be orders. That's according to a former Twitter employee whose identity was hidden while testifying to the committee.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: FORMER TWITTER EMPLOYEE
utterances.sentences: It felt as if a mob was being organized. And they were gathering together their weaponry and their logic and their reasoning behind why they were prepared to fight.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Members of the Committee say they were finding similar types of chatter across social media platforms.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RASKIN
utterances.sentences: "Calling all patriots, be in Washington, DC January the 6th. This wasn't organized by any group. DJT has invited us and it's going to be wild."Some of the online rhetoric turned to openly homicidal and white nationalist such as why don't we just kill them, every last Democrat down to the last man, woman and child and it's time for the day of the rope. White Revolution is the only solution. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: TheDonald.Win, an openly racist and antisemitic site became a venue for those considering violence to exchange ideas.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RASKIN
utterances.sentences: on that site, many shared plans and violent threats. Bring handcuffs and wait near the tunnels wrote one user. A commenter replied suggesting zip ties instead. One post encouraged others to come with body armor, knuckles, shields, bats, pepper spray, whatever it takes. All of those were used on the sixth.The post concluded, join your local Proud Boys chapter as well. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: According to the committee, the Proud Boys a far-right militia was active during this time, preparing for January 6.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RASKIN
utterances.sentences: The Proud Boys launched an encrypted chat called the Ministry of Self Defense. The committee obtained hundreds of these messages with show strategic and tactical planning about January the 6th including maps of Washington DC that pinpoint the location of Police.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Even more alarming, some of the people making plans in the Proud Boys and in the Oathkeepers, another right wing militia had direct ties to people close to Donald Trump.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RASKIN
utterances.sentences: One such Ally was Lieutenant General Michael Flynn, Trump's former National Security Adviser. This photo from December 12 shows Flynn and Patrick Byrne, another Trump ally, guarded by indicted Oathkeeper Roberto Minuta. Another view of the scene shows Oathkeepers leader Stewart Rhodes in the picture as well.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Both Minuta and Rhodes were charged with seditious conspiracy conspiring to use force against the federal government. They pleaded not guilty. But late last year.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Jury has reached a verdict in the seditious conspiracy trial for alleged leaders of the far right Oathkeepers.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Rhodes and another Oathkeeper were found guilty of seditious conspiracy. Three others they were tried with were convicted on lesser charges. Minuta's trial is underway. More than a dozen Oathkeepers and Proud Boys have been charged with seditious conspiracy. According to the committee, longtime Trump ally, Roger Stone had ties to these groups.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RASKIN
utterances.sentences: In the same time frame, Stone communicated with both the Proud Boys and the Oathkeepers regularly. The committee obtained encrypted content from a group chat called Friends of Stone, FOS, which included Stone, Rhodes, Tarrio, and Ali Alexander.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Tario is Enrique Tarrio, leader of the Proud Boys.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: There are some missing pieces in the public record, such as what, if anything, did Donald Trump or anyone inside the White House know about the organizing by the far right militias.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: The night before January 6, President Trump instructed his Chief of Staff Mark Meadows to contact both Roger Stone and Michael Flynn, regarding what would play out the next day. Ms. Hutchinson, is it your understanding that Mr. Meadows called Mr. Stone on the 5th?

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: I'm under the impression that Mr. Meadows did complete both a call to Mr. Stone and General Flynn the evening of the 5th.

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: And do you know what they talked about that evening, Ms. Hutchinson.

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: I think what's important is that he was going through the process of selling that the election was stolen. And then in convincing folks that look, if you believe that election was stolen from you, violence is the only answer quite honestly. I mean, that's kind of the American tradition. If you -- if you truly believe that the Constitution is being disobeyed, every American would actually be on the Capitol.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Up next, Donald Trump puts the squeeze on justice.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You're obviously well aware of what Donald Trump was doing in terms of his election fraud claims. Did you have any apprehension of becoming Deputy Attorney General?

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: No, I didn't have any concerns about that. I had a great deal of confidence in the team. I want to be part of the team. You want to be there when it matters.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You can't ever accept when they steal and rake and rob. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: After Attorney General Bill Barr resigned, Richard Donoghue was appointed to the number two position in the Department of Justice the Deputy to Jeffrey Rosen, the new Acting Attorney General. The two men inherited a department under constant and public attack by the sitting President of the United States fighting to hold on to an election he falsely claimed had been stolen.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Trump thought the Justice Department was an arm of his presidency in a way for him to tell them what to do and they should do his bidding and what he wanted.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: As the new targets of Trump's ire, Rosen and Donahue fielded near daily complaints from Donald Trump.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) JEFFREY ROSEN, FORMER U.S. ACTING ATTORNEY GENERAL: Between December 23 and January 3, the President either called me or met with me virtually every day. The common element of all of this was the president, expressing his dissatisfaction that the Justice Department in his view had not done enough to investigate election fraud. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But they were investigating. The Department of Justice had been debunking Trump's wild election fraud lies one by one, but President Trump chose to not listen. On a December 27 phone call with Rosen and Donoghue, President Trump said the department had an obligation to, quote tell people that this was an illegal corrupt election, despite no evidence of widespread fraud.Trump also pressed them to publicly, "just say the election was corrupt, and leave the rest to me and the Republican congressman."

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: That was an exact quote from the President indicated that he had some political Avenue he wanted to pursue with the Congress, but by him telling us that we should say publicly that it was corrupt, that concerned me.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: What he intended, was for the Department of Justice to say we have indications that there was corruption, because from there, you can take that seed of doubt. And Donald Trump and Republican members of Congress can water it, they can grow that that doubt. And then through there, you could do things like get people to vote against certification on January 6.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: As long as Rosen and Donoghue were in charge, they told the president they would not publicly back his false election fraud claims. So Trump had to find someone who would help him do what he wanted to steal the election.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: Jeff Clark's name had come up on December 27, in the phone call with the President. He brought it up and said, look, people are telling me I should change the leadership. People are telling me that you too, are not doing your job. I hear Jeff Clark is great. People tell me he could get in there and do something. And it was surprising to me.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Surprising because the President would have no reason to even know who Jeffrey Clark was.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: EVAN PEREZ, CNN SENIOR JUSTCIE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Even within the department, you know, very few people had really heard of Jeffrey Clark.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But Donald Trump had unbeknownst to Rosen and Donohue, Pennsylvania Republican Congressman Scott Perry had brought Clark to the Oval Office to meet with President Trump on December 22, the day after Perry had been amongst Republican members of Congress, who joined Trump at the White House to discuss overturning the 2020 election.Trump also mentioned Jeff Clark on a separate call with Rosen. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ROSEN
utterances.sentences: He made what I regarded as a peculiar reference. I don't remember the exact quote, but it was something about did I know Jeff Clark, or did I know who he was or something like that? I was quizzical as to how does the President even know Mr. Clark? Rosen confronted Clark, who admitted he had broken the long standing policy, governing communication between the Justice Department and the White House.White House lawyers Pat Cipollone and Patrick Philbin also intervened and warned Clark to not communicate with the White House. Clark agreed. But just two days later escalated the situation with an email that set off a series of events that would rock the Justice Department. (END VIDEO CLIP)
